body: @roji This looks like a limitation with OPENJSON. May also impact spatial types, since they are also "CLR types" as far as SQL Server is concerned.

@ajcvickers that sounds right. The workaround here would be to not use the OPENJSON/WITH syntax, but rather OPENJSON without WITH, at which point a regular CAST from nvarchar would hopefully give us the correct representation. 

Let's discuss next steps in the Monday meeting.

Confirmed that there is no regression for spatial: Contains with geometry/geography wasn't supported before. In 7.0:

```c#
var points = new[] { new Point(3.5, 4.5), new Point(99, 99) };
_ = await ctx.Blogs.Where(b => points.Contains(b.Point)).ToListAsync();
```

... translated to:

```sql
SELECT [b].[Id], [b].[Name], [b].[Point]
FROM [Blogs] AS [b]
WHERE [b].[Point] IN (geometry::Parse('POINT (3.5 4.5)'), geometry::Parse('POINT (99 99)'))
```

... which errored with:

```
Microsoft.Data.SqlClient.SqlException (0x80131904): Invalid operator for data type. Operator equals equal to, type equals geometry.
```

Note that SQL Server doesn't seem to even allow using the equality operator, which would be consistent with IN not being supported; the following errors in the same way:

```sql
SELECT [b].[Id], [b].[Name], [b].[Point]
FROM [Blogs] AS [b]
WHERE [b].[Point] = geometry::STGeomFromText('POINT (3.5 4.5)', 0);
```

I'm assuming OGC STEquals would need to be used instead.

Regardless, making geometry collections work in general is tracked via #30630.

issue.title: Support mapping (and querying) of geometry collections

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Issues that have been approved but are not scheduled a specific release.

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
GIS has a concept of a collection of geometry objects; this is represented by NetTopologySuite's [GeometryCollection](https://nettopologysuite.github.io/NetTopologySuite/api/NetTopologySuite.Geometries.GeometryCollection.html) type, which extends Geometry and which we map to the database geometry/geography types (e.g. [GeometryCollection](https://learn.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/spatial/geometrycollection) in SQL Server). In most databases we also translate some spatial functions.

As part of #29427, we're allowing to map a .NET collection of any supported type to a JSON column in the database; but since collections of spatial objects have a special representation, we're excluding that specifically. Since GeometryCollection already implements `IEnumerable<Geometry>`, we probably don't want to also allow mapping e.g. `Geometry[]`. However, most database don't allow unpacking a geometry collection to a queryable table (PG supports this via [ST_Dump](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_Dump.html)); this means mapping `Geometry[]` to a regular JSON string column in the database does an advantage (queryability) over mapping to a database geometry collection.

Note: SQL Server OPENJSON doesn't natively support geometry, i.e. does not allow using `geometry` in its WITH clause. But we can still get WKT out as a string and just wrap it in a function which returns the geometry object.

issue.title: [release/8.0] Make Contains work again over hierarchyid

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
Fixes #31912

### Description

The primitive collection improvements to 8.0 changed the translation of Contains to use OPENJSON with WITH, but that's incompatible with hierarchyid (SQL Server CLR type).

### Customer impact

Queries which apply Contains to a parameter list of HierarchyId no longer work in 8.0.

### How found

Customer reported.

### Regression

Yes (when the community hierarchyid package was used)

### Testing

Added.

### Risk

Very low, the mechanism to transform the incompatible OPENJSON with WITH to OPENJSON without WITH already existed for other purposes; this change only extends its usage for hierarchyid.
